conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
At time t1, Object A has a certain velocity and Object B has a different velocity.
The exact values of velocities at t1 are not necessary for determining acceleration.
For Object A, the graph shows a curve decreasing in velocity as time progresses.
The slope of Object A's curve at t1 is negative, indicating deceleration.
For Object B, the graph shows a curve increasing in velocity as time progresses.
The slope of Object B's curve at t1 is positive, indicating acceleration.
Since Object A's slope at t1 is negative and Object B's slope at t1 is positive, their accelerations are not the same.
Object A is experiencing a negative acceleration (deceleration), while Object B is experiencing a positive acceleration.
The accelerations of Object A and Object B at time t1 are different.
Final Answer: No, Object A and Object B do not have the same acceleration at time t1.
